ygData.subject: Re: grammatical evolution
ygData.msgSnippet: Jean-Baptise, Thank you for your explanation.  I understand your motivations and appreciate the idea.  You are interested in being able to formalize encodings

Jean-Baptise,

Thank you for your explanation.  I understand your motivatio=
ns and
appreciate the idea.  You are interested in being able to formalize
=
encodings so that they can be expressed in a way that is better
understood.=
  I do not have any disagreement with this idea.  My
uncertainty was only d=
irected at grammatical encoding in particular
and its search space-related =
properties.  I think perhaps my use of
the word "formal" seemed to be an at=
tack on formalization in general,
which was not intended.

By the way, have=
 you thought about whether your approach can describe
DNA encoding?  Do you=
 think it should be able to?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jean-Baptis=
te Mouret / Mandor
<mandor@...> wrote:
>
> 		Hi Ken.,
> 
> From: "Kenneth S=
tanley" <kstanley@...>
> 
> > I am not dismissing GE, but I would want to h=
ear an argument
> > supporting it more from the encoding and search spaces =
side rather
> > than from the formal languages side.
> 
> I think you mix t=
wo concepts: the tool used to express encodings and
> the encoding.
> 
> An=
y encoding will be expressed in a form and I think you will agree
> that th=
is form should be as formal as possible. A formal way to
> express encoding=
s would allow us to rely on a solid basis as we would
> be able to reproduc=
e experiments more easily and to draw a real
> picture of what our encoding=
 is (instead of relying on poorly defined
> concepts, figures, etc. to expl=
ain our work). For instance, a formal
> framework should make easy to defin=
e variants of a same encoding to
> efficiently understand which biasesre us=
eful for a given class of
> problems. Moreover, once we have a good formali=
sm, we can often think
> about more complex and abstract concepts.
> 
> It'=
s clear that the ideal formalism should allow to express any
> encoding: it=
's a tool to explore encodings (at least a family of
> encodings) and to mo=
dify the search space.
> 
> Overall, I think that designing such a formalis=
m would be a decisive
> step to make future progress in our field because w=
e really need a
> more solid basis.
> 
> So, the next question is: which fo=
rmalism? We proposed (in the linked
> paper) to use attribute grammars and =
operators inspired by genetic
> programming. They are powerful and many con=
cepts can be easily
> expressed. For example it's easy to define a direct-e=
ncoding for
> neural-networks. Howerver, some neuro-evolution systems (espe=
cially
> NEAT) cannot be fully described because they are not only encoding=
s
> (e.g. in NEAT, there's the diversity preservation mechanism). I'm
> rea=
lly not sure that it's the best possible formalism but it's almost
> the on=
ly one I know.
> 
> In the previously linked paper, we designed a modular a=
nd hierarchical
> encoding with this formalism (i.e. we designed a specific=

> grammar). This shows at least that it's possible to express such
> conce=
pts in the formalism. As a consequence, we now have a
> hierarchical and mo=
dular encoding and we can ask the next question
> (the one you ask): are th=
ese features really needed in an encoding?
> Our first results show that it=
 can lead to interesting results but
> it's not a definitive answer. The po=
int is to have a solid tool to
> investigate this question.
> 
> Best regar=
ds,
> -- 
> Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
> http://animatlab.lip6.fr/~moure=
t
> tel : (+33) 6 28 35 10 49
>
